intro: Tachiadenus carinatus, commonly known as the waxy beggar-ticks, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and small, clustered flowers. The plant features a slender, branching stem covered in fine, waxy hairs, which help reduce water loss in arid environments. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a distinctive white or grayish bloom, contributing to its ornamental appeal. Tachiadenus carinatus is adapted to dry, rocky habitats and is often found in desert scrub and chaparral ecosystems.
